awd_titl_txt: RAPID International Type I: Understanding the Nature of US-China Research Collaborations on COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1. 
During the SARS-COV-2 pandemic, scientists from the U.S. and China collaborated more frequently on pandemic-related research papers than they had on papers in general over the previous five years, underscoring the value of international collaboration in addressing global crises. What remains largely unknown is how such collaboration occurred. The primary objective of this study is to examine how U.S.-China research collaboration on COVID-19 occurred and, in particular, how scientific nationalism and global competitiveness shaped these collaborations. The project will move beyond standard bibliometric analysis of research collaborations to conduct mixed method survey research to better understand how collaborative relationships were established or maintained and the challenges experienced or overcome by scientists collaborating on COVID-19 research. The findings will generate crucial insights on how to effectively balance the need to rapidly produce knowledge, overcome disruptions to research processes, and ensure research abides by established regulatory protocols. The long-ranging impact will be to enhance understanding of how science and technology cooperation can more effectively be supported in the future, especially in times of global crisis.


Part 2. 
The research addresses the intensifying intersection between geopolitics and global science by engaging directly with US and Chinese scientists collaborating on COVID-19. The study employs a multi-disciplinary approach incorporating frameworks from research policy studies and securitization studies to identify the range of challenges scientists experienced during the pandemic and how scholarly relationships were created or maintained. Data will be based on a survey and interviews among US and Chinese scientists who have coauthored a US-China scientific paper on COVID-19. Among the key data analyses will be to examine the extent to which securitization may have supported or hindered the COVID-19 research collaboration, as well as its impact on future collaboration. Additional analyses will investigate potential differences based on whether the scientific research was federally funded. The findings will contribute to current understandings of the relationship between the nation-state and international science cooperation, particularly the impact that global crises and geopolitics may have on scientists’ abilities to engage in the global knowledge network to produce knowledge on urgent cross-border issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project engaged directly with scientists involved in US-China collaborations on COVID-19-related research to understand their experiences collaborating during a time when normal research processes were disrupted. The findings confirm and extend knowledge, theory, and research related to scientists' engagement in cross-border scientific networks and to the intersection between scientists' research networks and capacities and federal security interests. The findings have been and are in the process of being disseminated through peer-reviewed journal articles, conference presentations, and editorials. 

The projects' findings demonstrate how social capital embedded in scientists networks played a vital role in scientists' capacities to quickly produce knowledge related to COVID-19. Scientists collaborated mostly with individuals whom they had prior working relationships as opposed to forming new relationships with unknown scientists. Furthermore, scientists collaborated with others who shared their interests, who they trusted, and whose knowledge, skills, and resources complemented their own. In other words, pre-existing trust-based relationships among US and Chinese scientists allowed for them to quickly and effectively pool their knowledge, skills, and resources to produce knowledge. Additionally, the collaborative relationships enhanced both US and Chinese scientists' capabilities to produce knowledge related to COVID-19. For US scientists, this was especially true at the beginning of the pandemic when most of the COVID-19 cases were in China, and US scientists relied on Chinese scientists for access to data and other knowledge surrounding COVID-19. These findings point to the importance of having a culture that fosters the development and maintenance of cross-border scientific networks at all times, so that scientists are able to establish long-term, trust-based relationships that allow them to quickly and effectively mobilize knowledge, skills, and resources to produce knowledge on pressing issues.

Beyond scientific networks and social capital, the findings regarding challenges scientists experienced demonstrated that many of the challenges associated with COVID-19 did not have a significant impact on scientists' capacities to engage in international research collaboration. Scientists indicated that the information communication technologies to which they had access were sufficient to allow them to collaborate despite not being able to collaborate in-person. The main challenges associated with conducting research were lab closures, supply chain issues, and access to funding, but none of these were unique to collaborating internationally. Further, scientists indicated that many of their prior collaboration experiences involved distance collaboration, so collaborating during the pandemic when travel was restricted did not necessarily change how collaboration would have occurred otherwise. However, in some cases, travel restrictions and a lack of face-to-face interaction limited scientists' capacities to fully undertake research. In situations in which scientists had plans for team members to work in each others' labs and engage in bench work, they indicated that an inability to travel limited the extent to which work was able to be completed. In these cases, less research was conducted than would have been possible otherwise, but they were still able to continue their collaboration remotely. Despite these cases, the findings overwhelmingly point to the fact that pre-existing network ties, collaboration experiences, and infrastructure were already in place reducing the severity of challenges and allowing scientists to effectively collaborate internationally. 

Lastly, the findings provide valuable insights into the impact that geopolitical tensions and US securitization practices have had on US and Chinese scientists' collaboration behaviors. In terms of their COVID-19 related publications, most US scientists indicated they had few concerns about government scrutiny of their work and ties to their foreign collaborators. This was because their research did not involve sensitive information, or they did not receive government funding to conduct their research. They also highlighted their desires to contribute knowledge to help solve a pressing global challenge, which trumped most concerns they had about government scrutiny. However, US-based ethnically Chinese scientists discussed a climate of fear and uncertainty due to US federal prosecutions and unclear policies. They rated fears of government surveillance as a significantly greater challenge than did US-based non-ethnic Chinese scientists. For US-based ethnically Chinese scientists, their concerns have resulted in restricting relationships with China-based scientists to those whom they know or cutting ties with China-based scientists altogether. It has also resulted in overly cautious behavior to ensure that they will not become targets of the US government or their universities. China-based scientists also discussed impacts on their working relationships with US scientists. They discussed experiencing distancing by US colleagues and more restrictions on collaboration and exchange due to changes in US university and government policies. Therefore, the climate of fear and uncertainty is resulting in reductions in ties between US and Chinese scientists. Given the important role that established ties played in mobilizing knowledge, skills, and resources, reductions in opportunities to establish and maintain cross-border relationships may ultimately limit US and Chinese scientists' capacities to produce knowledge and help solve global challenges.
